description:
I am using devstack to set up a test environment.
I see the following erroneous behavior when using python-novaclient (freshly pulled from github this evening) to administer keystone:

>>> from novaclient import client as adminclient
>>> from novaclient import keystone
>>> conn = adminclient.HTTPClient("admin", "password", "demo", "http://10.10.10.2:5000/v2.0/")
>>> kc = keystone.Client(conn)
>>> kc.tenants.create('test01')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/tom/git/python-novaclient/novaclient/keystone/tenants.py", line 68, in create
    return self._create('/tenants', params, "tenant")
  File "/home/tom/git/python-novaclient/novaclient/base.py", line 126, in _create
    resp, body = self.api.client.post(url, body=body)
  File "/home/tom/git/python-novaclient/novaclient/client.py", line 137, in post
    return self._cs_request(url, 'POST', **kwargs)
  File "/home/tom/git/python-novaclient/novaclient/client.py", line 121, in _cs_request
    **kwargs)
  File "/home/tom/git/python-novaclient/novaclient/client.py", line 104, in request
    raise exceptions.from_response(resp, body)
novaclient.exceptions.BadRequest: Expecting a unique Tenant Name (HTTP 400)
>>> print("aaaaahhhh!")

The following json is generated by novaclient and as shown above doesn't work (I tested with curl too):
{"tenant": {"enabled": true, "id": "test01", "description": null}}

Using curl again, I swap "id" with "name" as below and it works, my tenant is created and auto-incremented id is automatically assigned to my new tenant:
{"tenant": {"enabled": true, "name": "test01", "description": null}}
title: novaclient.keystone.Client incorrectly sends 'id' instead of 'name'

comments.content: The keystone client stub was removed from novaclient per bug 924588 on 03Feb2012.  python-keystoneclient should be used directly for keystone interaction.
